comments.raw_text:
The most important requirement is that the name not suggest any endorsement by Mozilla and not be confusable with the trademark.  It's quite difficult to suggest similarity but not endorsement in such limited space.  A name with a clear suggestion of genericity (e.g., "Somefox") might achieve that but might be considered derogatory to the trademark.

I think the best approach is to choose a name of related subject matter, if possible, but with no obvious shared morphemes.  Red Hat's choice of "Fedora" is exemplary.  Some ideas:

- "Vulpes", the genus name for true foxes.  Might be hard to pronounce.  A corresponding logo would have to be chosen carefully to avoid confusion.

- "Dino", or an abbreviation of the name of some dinosaur species other than Tyrannosaurus rex (the Mozilla mascot).

- "Dynamo".  Positive ring, ends with the first two letters of "Mozilla", and suggests content more "dynamic" (variable) than the official builds.

comments.text:
While the suggestion of "IceWeasel" makes me giggle, I also don't think it's suitable... Best to let that issue untouched here. Additionally: "weasel" isn't a very appealing word; it harkens to much-maligned monikers like "SquirrelFish"; and it has no inherent meaning other than as an inversion of Firefox.

As it might be helpful, I'll note that there are a few different use-cases for the "unofficial" branding...

1) Developers doing their own builds, at part of working on improving Firefox (or IceWeasel ;). Our code currently defaults to "Nightly", which bug 659568 seeks to change to something else.

2) Third parties seeking to distribute Firefox, but avoid dealing with trademark stuff. Debian could have gone this route were it available, or perhaps a vendor wanting to ship something that might not meet Firefox TM guidelines, but still comes with some branding to indicate it's part of the community. [tl;dr: XXX::Firefox as Chromium::Chrome]

3) Third parties seeking to distribute a browser butwho  don't want to create their own branding (or lack the skill to do so in a polished way). Presumably they'd still want to customize it somewhat, to make it their own... A branding name/logo that is easily tweakable and customizable would be nice here. As, for example, people clearly like to do so with the existing names (FireFoo, FooFire, Fire/Ice, Thunder/Lighting, etc). 

4) Potentially, ephemeral builds produced by Mozilla in the course of development... EG: TryServer builds, hourly tinderbox builds, etc. Needs discussion before it could happen, but I'll toss it out here anyway.

I'm ... not sure I understand the objections to using Iceweasel.  The only actual downside I can think of is that it would make it less clear whether people were using Debian's version or not, but since the main point of having an unencumbered brand is to allow people to distribute modified vedrsions without approval, and that this is exactly the purpose for which Debian has adopted the branding, I don't think this is a big deal.(In reply to Mike Hommey [:glandium] from comment #13)

The fact that Debian had to come up with their own branding is certainly unfortunate, and the need to continue using it is somewhat annoying, but I certainly can't see any benefit to trying to pretend it didn't happen, especially in trying to make things easier for those who come after -- why shouldn't the solution reference the problems?

I also think it does a decent job of conveying the idea "like Firefox, but with no official ties".

Plus, there's already art for it ;-).
